definition.value: A <belief about control over valued outcomes> that attribute control to factors outside oneself.
A <stimulus> that is located outside the person.
A <stimulus> by which the person experiences an externally-generated positive physical or psychological state subsequent to a response.
An <extrinsic motivation> that derives from external rewards, punishments or pressure regarding a behaviour.
Pressure can include persuasion.
A <social influence behaviour> where some family member exerts an influence on the behaviour of another.
A <bodily process> that reduces fear without necessarily reducing the threat.
A <mental process> that reduces the person’s fear.
A <feedback process to a person> in which information about a behaviour is received by the person enacting the behaviour.
A <mental feedback process> relating the behaviour to identity.
A <process> in which information about a bodily process is received by the person.
A <subjective affective feeling> that one is not exposed to harm or risk of harm.
A <subjective affective feeling> of pressure from other people to act, think or feel in a particular way.
A <conditioned reinforcer> whose effect has been caused by pairing with multiple primary reinforcers.
A <mental disposition> to be self-efficacious across a wide range of situations and behaviours.
A <goal> that concerns protecting or increasing the person’s resources.
This class is used for goals relating to personal resources that may be social, financial, material or psychological.
A <social group attribute> in which a majority of members of a group have the belief.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.
A <social group attribute> a behaviour is common within a social group.
A group could be a population.
A <social group attribute> in which members of the group share an evaluative belief of a behaviour.
A group could be a population.
A <behavioural disposition> of members of a social group to enable each others’ engagement in group actions.
A <fear reduction mental process> that has a negative outcome.
‘Negative’ is inherently subjective. It could mean a bad outcome for the person, the people or those around them, or society more generally.

label.value: high capability to enact a behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute>in terms of behavioural capability being high.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: high motivational disposition to change behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute> in terms of motivational disposition to change behaviour being high.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: high opportunity to enact a behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute> in terms of  behavioural opportunity being high.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.
A <mental disposition> to engage behaviour that has the attribute of impulsiveness.
This class links to the class ‘impulsiveness’ as a behavioural attribute.
<Judging> that devalues information or its relevance to a situation.’ Under judging.
<Reflective thinking> about the truth, accuracy or relevance of information about something
A <drive process>in which the physiological need is determined prenatally.
A <behavioural intention> to enact a behaviour with one or more others.

label.value: intention not to enact a behaviour

definition.value: A <behavioural intention> not to enact a behaviour.
This means intention to actively not enact a behaviour (negative intention)
A <behavioural intention> to enact a behaviour.
This means intention to actively enact a behaviour (positive intention)
A <schedule of reinforcement> in which the event following the behaviour occurs on some but not all occasions.
A <stimulus> that is located inside the person.
A <belief about the cause of a behaviour> where the cause is a characteristic of the person enacting the behaviour.
A <belief about control over valued outcomes> that attribute control to oneself.
A <stimulus> by which the person experiences an internally-generated positive physical or psychological state subsequent to a response.
<Judging> that results in a belief about a causal relationship between two or more entities
<Knowledge regarding a threat> that includes how to avoid it.
<Knowledge> about how to achieve a goal.
A <low opportunity to enact a behaviour> resulting from legal restriction.
A <temporal behavioural opportunity> for recreational activities.
<Reflective reasoning> in which rules of inference are applied to arrive at conclusions.

label.value: low capability to enact a behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute>in terms of behavioural capability being low.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: low motivational disposition to change behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute> in terms of motivational disposition to change behaviour being low.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: low opportunity to enact a behaviour

definition.value: A <personal attribute> in terms of having low behavioural opportunity.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: low opportunity to enact a goal-directed behaviour

definition.value: <Low opportunities to enact a behaviour> that is goal-directed.

label.value: low physical opportunity to enact a behaviour

definition.value: <Low opportunity to enact a behaviour> where the opportunity is physical.
An <personal attribute> of self-efficacy belief that is low.
This is a fuzzy set and can only be used if operationalised.

label.value: low social opportunity to enact a behaviour

definition.value: <Low opportunity to enact a behaviour> where the opportunity is social.

label.value: mechanism of action through reinforcement process

definition.value: A <behaviour change intervention mechanism of action> in which the causal influence occurs in a reinforcement process.

label.value: mechanism of action through social group attribute

definition.value: A <behaviour change intervention mechanism of action> in which the causal influence affects a social group attribute.
